dynamic.content:
1,5 years ago I decided in favor of buying a Yoga 7. Now I have multiple cracks on the plastic bezel around the screen and the plastic is shattered around both hinges. Even though I'm not a heavy duty user and mainly use it at home. Warranty repair denied claiming its due to physical damage (no it's not). Paying for the repair from my pocket, which requires replacing the entire screen section, would cost 70% of the original purchase cost.

Looking around I could hardly find any matte 2,8K display laptops on the market where I live and I'm aiming for that due to switching to Linux and needing a display without fractional scaling. The only other options I was able to find are a couple of Lenovos - Ideapad Pros and Yoga 7 Slims - priced between $1100-1400. Or some Lenovo T14s around $2200. Compared to these the Framework is not a bad deal at all, especially factoring in the repairability.

The only valid downside I agree with is the rounded corners on the screen offered only with squared bezels. I mean it just seems so straightforward to create bezels with the same rounded corners around the edges that I can't even fathom why Framework hasn't been doing it.

I came to this video thanks to a LTT video when people asked Linus to react to you (and he give you the reason), I agree, Framework laptops are very expensive and I suppose that is not their fault, as you say, they’re a small company and that makes difficult to negotiate better prices for the components, it would be great if they grow as a company and bring better prices.

He’s ABSOLUTELY RIGHT, so why have I paid my final payment for the even more expensive Intel Core Ultra version?

It’s because he underestimates the true value proposition that the Framework 13 offers.

Firstly, he’s misunderstood the true cost: all he talks about is the upfront cost, when it’s the savings on upgrade that redress the balance. 

E.g. to upgrade to the Ryzen 5 motherboard in his video it costs just $419.  This gives an indication as to what I can expect in future…that’s a bargain!!  Plus, as Framework grows in popularity, economies of scale should push the price down.

Secondly, when you upgrade your motherboard, you can repurpose your old motherboard eg as a server and there are free downloadable 3D printer case designs for Framework motherboards. 

Therefore, upon upgrading I get TWO computers not one new one…you need to add in the price of a free secondhand computer/server into the equation.

Thirdly, computers break..it’s a fact of life and the cost of repair is negligible with Framework compared to any other brand…and some brands are impossible to repair which means you have to replace the ENTIRE LAPTOP.  This huge cost is missing from his analysis.

Fourthly, he doesn’t properly factor the value of recycling and waste prevention…he’s just another mindless consumer who moans about the environment but does nothing about it even when the solution is in his hands.  The cognitive dissonance is palpable but he dismisses it. 

Lastly, as a Linux user, it’s fantastic to have a brand that’s put support of Linux as a primary goal.

Here's the thing, are they shipping bad hardware or just not the "bleeding edge?" The whole model is around maintainability. You're right, it isn't apples-to-apples, but maybe that's the point: For what it's offering, at its price point, with what it offers in the future (and of course warranties and what have you. After market support...).
Why does Ridge Wallet hate their customers and want to saddle them with a massive gold-colored liability designed by a deranged billionaire?

Just because it is the only repairable laptop out there, doesn't mean every downside you give to it is caused by it's repair ability. If microsoft wanted to make a repairable laptop, they could make one far cheaper than framework just because microsoft is bigger.
Glad I saw this cybertruck promo by Ridge on this video because now I'm never buying from them again.

I'm so very tempted at a Framework system.. But yeah, as you mention - Price vs. Specs.. It is really tough to justify the price, despite of the excellent idea, and the ability to re-use your old hardware into a mini PC, and what not else.

About the price thing, it must be compared with laptops of the same kind, this is not a cheap laptop, first, it must be compared to laptops made with metal frames, second, in the work oriented laptop, the ones for enterprise, I actually think that this is one of the problems, not the price but the specific section of the market it is covering, the price is normal for that section of the market, ypu mentioned lenovo, and that one, even when it has cheaper laptop with similar specs, has laptops for this section of the market that are similarly priced, this is also the section of the market that apple shoukd cover, outside of the people that buy it to display the logo and would be fine with a 500usd laptop

For a long time, as the price of Chanel increased, I no longer thought I could afford it. I think I'll be happy that I have the  kisluxs  as my travel bag that I don't have to take care of. By the way, I'm sure no one will have a hard time telling the difference. Thanks for the comparison.

I am not sure how Framework are getting around these new SOCs that are required to have soldered RAM for AI. Now Intel and AMD no longer are making ultrabook chips with socketed RAM, along with Snapdragon, I suspect that is the end of RAM upgradeability. Most Intel, AMD and Snapdragon allow you to upgrade the SSD so I am not sure what Frameworks USP will mean next year? I would not be surprised if they struggle. LPCAMM2 looks like it is mainly for pro & gaming PCs due to the size, but maybe they will work, although they are currently 2-3X more expensive and upgrading 16GB to 32GB means you have to buy a 32GB CAMM2 board rather than just add 16GB. 

The business model looks dicey hence the prices being poor value.

According to the comments it might be a hot take, but I agree with Austin here. Maybe he didn't elaborate to the extent that Framework supporters might have wanted, but it definitely conveyed the point to the consumer that needed to be made. Repairability is great. Being able to upgrade is great. Until it is the best option compared to the competition, with all other things being equal, it will continue to be a hard sell. Props to Framework for being one of the first to offer what enthusiasts have been asking for, just hopefully eventually they're able to get to a future where they can price in line with other manufacturers, and hopefully other manufacturers follow suit with this model as well. That's what we as consumers should be pushing for.

I'll be honest guys. I wouldn't call the ridge wallet as a wallet, it's just a fancy card holder. It's feels really wrong for calling it a wallet and no youtube who is promoting it is questioning it at all.
Saying the only thing better engineered than a cybertruck is the ridge wallet is a really low bar

Nothing he said was wrong, it is a rather poor value compared to a mass produced device, but probably his worst comparison was custom keyboards, which are also often a pretty terrible value for money, a decent keyboard only cost $20-50, a nice custom keyboard costs upwards of $400, so in terms of scale on a semi-custom laptop, around double the price isn't bad value and they could come up with more options.

I think it's a really disingenuous to compare to the yoga 7 SALE price. If you bump your ram, storage, and screen back down on the framework to actually match the yoga and the price someone would realistically pay, the delta isn't as bad as you make it out to be.

Not saying the still ~$300 premium isn't significant, but I don't think it's too unfair a price to pay for something that will be able to theoretically stay around a lot longer and not be completely replaced when I want to upgrade in a couple years. That yoga is almost entirely irreparable too. You break anything on it and it's essentially waste.

In my eyes, you buy the initial unit for 300 more, upgrade two years later like you likely would for the yoga at ~$400 like you mentioned, and you've already broken even. Any upgrades after that is money saved. It's a longer game but I much prefer that path myself.

Framework is still a Young Company, as such the Early Adopter Price will be around for some time. In the long run the idea is solid, I do hope it catches on with other makers, however I only see the greedy Corps looking at this idea and turning it into a "Things as a Service monthly fee" model.
I think the cost vs performance is fair. The comment about why not allow more keyboard customization makes me think is is not familiar with the crazy modularity of the larger laptop 💻

Y’all so salty in the comments 😂😂 idc how upgradable or repairable the laptop is. I’m not paying 1300 for something with keyboard flex and a ryzen 5. I’d love to see how many people ACTUALLY keep a framework 13 for 10 years and how much it would cost over the life of it

"There are some downsides" to a laptop I can repair myself on a flight at 5am in the morning in time to make a 9am meeting at my destination? The kind of downsides that mean I can (and have) upgraded it MULTIPLE times over the last three years while saving hundreds of dollars? Price comparison aside, I'm sorry, but you missed the ENTIRE point of this laptop. It is A LITERAL anti-MacBook.

I don't majorly disagree with anything that Austin brings up here (and I own a framework laptop), except for maybe one thing.  I think to review this laptop price and spec wise against other laptops  so flatly does a major injustice to the purpose and motivation behind framework.  I think it misses the idea that this laptop allows for users to take back their rights to do what they want with their computers.  If we review this from just a regular laptop review perspective, then yeah there is going to be better laptops for a better price.  Go and buy your absolutely un-repairable dell xps laptop.  But as long as we do that, we just continue to pay money to the companies who continue to prove that we dont actually own anything anymore.  I at least feel like with Framework, I am helping to push the cause forward towards a world with better repairability and sustainability.

Not everybody wants Redmond's garbage OS nor is everyone scared of very minor assembly. Clearly this review completely misses the point - Framework is meant to be upgradeable. Yeah its a bit more expensive up front - In a year or two when tis time for the new processor or to repair something that broke... All the sudden its cheaper than having to buy an entirely new laptop. Also - Ryzen 7040 did come out a little over a year ago. Until the end of July there was nothing for Framework to upgrade it with. They're normally about a quarter behind the mega corporations - Intentionally - With upgrades... So Ryzen 300 models are probably coming in the fall.
Austin Evans is a hardcore Apple, Tesla, and Ridge wallet meatrider and just funded the scammers

I think you made a handful of valid points (slightly older cpu) on not getting it; but that Lenovo you mentioned is ON SALE, half the ram, half the SSD, and a lower quality screen. The points you made could be informative but if you’re going to suggest a different option then at least make sure both computers are in the same class.

Also volume pricing is a thing that bigger OEMs can get components cheaper vs Framework and, as you clearly demonstrated, Best Buy can eat the cost of the computer by slashing the price in hopes you buy something else.

I think if you’re going to do an actual “the reason to not buy a computer “ you need to make sure you are presenting true facts to make your point and not taking short cuts to make that point.

How does it make sense to compare the Yoga with half the RAM, storage, and lower resolution screen to the Framework? When I priced out a Yoga with actually similar specs it is around $1100. I'd gladly pay the slight premium for the still better display and customization/upgradability.

Definitely like everyone is saying, he's missing the mark. If anything, the price point is a little higher at the start, but the longevity is the main selling point. Oh it's time for a new processor, just replace the processor and motherboard components, and not have to buy a whole new laptop again. That's the point of this laptop, is to replace what you need as you need it instead of buying a new laptop.

Yeah having the cybertruck giveaway in your review shitting on the framework wasnt the play. It's fine that the laptop isnt for you, but I think overarchingly you missed the point. Its a laptop designed around being repairable and replaceable. Buy once and have something solid for 5+ years or maybe longer. This isnt a laptop for people who want to be on the bleeding edge. If they can afford a Microsoft surface laptop or xps 13 every 2 years and dont care about what happens to their old computer then yeah, do that. This is for people who want to keep their workhorse. That will take 20 minutes to repace the battery and appreciate how easy it is.

I wouldnt describe that crowd as enthusiast. Enthusiasts are buying razer blades or asus rog 14, or even macs. This is repair and sustainability focused. Webcam breaks? You can buy a replacement just like that.

The amount of lenovo laptops i see come through our workshop (more than any other brand for a hardware fault i might add), and the absolute pain in the ass those things are to repair, the framework approach is still the better a option even with the higher price
You have failed EVERYONE that advocates right to repair, and is somewhat eco-minded, and promoting ridge wallet and the cybertruck (that's built like a toy cart) is kinde two-faced

This video is absolutely correct. It´s from the perspective of normal customers, not tech enthusiasts. Normal customers don´t give a fuck about upgradeability - they are afraid of doing anything regarding tech stuff to computers. And, of course, when they see this upgradeable and easy-to-repair laptop vs normal stuff which is much cheaper - they buy cheaper. The problem with you as viewers of this video is that you are tech enthusiasts, tinkerers, and such - you care about stuff Framework is about, but people in general don´t.

my biggest gripe with framework is there ram and storage options, as you can get just as if not more performant ram or storage for a much lower price if you don't buy it through framework. This would make Austin's whole point about it being too expensive less valid, especially since most of frameworks customers at the moment would be knowledgeable enough to do that, also you don't have to use windows or even buy it through framework which is a major upside than other laptops where you are forced to pay full price for a windows license yes I know select Lenovo laptops let you select Ubuntu. Getting those three things separately bring the price down $200-$300.

I have to criticize Austin and the rest of the Techtubers out there for their outlandish expectations of Framework. I mean you want the laptop to be the same quality, performance and style as the other laptops with the same price, but still want repairability & modularity? This is not even mentioning the significantly smaller economies of scale considering consumers will not be buying new keyboards, webcams, chassis, etc if their laptops simply need a new battery?

This video, while informative, misses the whole point of Framework. It's the Fairphone of laptops, meant for you to buy into an ecosystem of parts and guides and sustainability. You're signing up for years' worth of support and tons of other things (including the free CAD files for most of the hardware).
If you're criticizing the price and talking about how there should be newer, fresher tech in their machines, the point is lost on you. They're constantly putting out new mainboards and shipping as fast as they presumably can; they're making 100% repairable devices designed with the technical user in mind; they're giving the users all the choices in the world when it comes to a laptop.
I'd say the price is entirely fair for that. Parts quality might have room for improvement, but that's not really what you talk about much here, is it?

Come on, Austin, eye on the ball.
I'm not even a Framework owner or investor. I just really believe in what they're doing, and if I needed a new laptop right now, I'd buy one in a heartbeat.

I have to agree with the conclusion of this. The cost is too high. When you can buy 2 decent, or 3 cheap laptops for the price of a single laptop ... it doesn't make sense. Yes, repairability has value, but it does not have 2-3x value. Don't forget those repairs are not free. If the motherboard breaks, that's another $600 for a new one or $300 for a previous gen. You're $1300 machine is now $1600-1900.

What's really telling is the people dunking on this video don't own a Framework themselves ... and I'd bet real money the primary reason is because of how expensive it is.

Sell me a repairable laptop for $200-300 more than an equivalent pre-built, then we'll talk. I won't even consider it when it's 2x+ the price. Especially for a super tiny 13" laptop with a cramped keyboard.

Okay Austin tell us how to make a company with a product like the framework with better specs and a lower price?
if enough people dont push back and support companies like framework we're going to start getting asked to pay a subscription service to use the web cam on our laptops and how much ram we get to use of whats already in our machines
also I dunno, maybe we really dont know the real cost of a laptop is when the company is paying their employees a proper wage
also are we still in a chip shortage? Framework will be at the bottom of the list for who gets allocated components, its logical they use hardware thats a bit dated, the turn around time at a start up is going to be much much lower than a gigantic company like Asus or Samsung.
So your paying Asus ROG price for a laptop... Just why

Before I decided to preorder a Framework laptop, I checked other options to see how much more the Framework would cost. And the difference is by no means as big as this guy tries very hard to make it look. Obviously the specs in his comparison are way off, so that doesn’t make sense in the first place. I compared the Framework with my specs (Ultra 5, 16 GB, 1 TB) to Lenovos ThinkPad, some laptops from Dell and Apples MacBook Air. The price difference was not big at all and Framework was not even more expensive in every scenario. 
As others have stated before, people who consider a Framework laptop won’t settle for a cheaper laptop instead if it means that they have to give up repairability and environmental benefits completely.

You have no right to complain about framework when you compare the garbage that Apple offers in comparison.  Apple computers are the biggest ripoff ever. They're designed to be a disposable paper bag and only have 8GB of RAM, which isn't even upgradable.  Framework would have to quadruple their prices to be as bad a rip off as Apple is.

Let's say it like this, if some people value repairability, modularity and opensource, they would pay anything for the price. Just like apple people, they would pay anything just to be in the ecosystem jusg because they value it more than the norms. So I don't think anything is overpriced if there isn't a A to A comparison, in the end it's just up to people to value how much are these features to them. What Austin said was from a casual user perspective, and most of the points are valid from it.

He has a point - Framework is pretty pricey for the power. If he can influence Framework to reconsider some of the prices we all win.
HOWEVER. Easy self repair, an open bios and excellent Linux support justify the price.
Plus, it's more about the money you save since you can update for relatively cheap and give your old board a second life as a SmartTV, game console or mini home server or anything else.

I keep thinking about this review. I own a framework laptop 13 and though I can't fully disagree with the video, the comparison feels a bit weird. I'm not a windows user either so I saved money by going the DIY route. All in All my Framework 13 would cost $1249 before tax, that's a build with a Ryzen 5 processor/ 32GB of DDR5/ 2TB SSD/ 120hz 2.8K screen. So when I look at what they're comparing it to I'm just thinking, but my laptop has 4X the memory and 4X the storage, plus the piece of mind that I can buy replacement parts easily. Don't get me wrong Framework laptops are priced more expensive than the competition. The gap starts to close a bit when you realize I chose these parts for a reason, and if I'm buying that Lenovo Yoga 7 I'm going to have to spend additional money to upgrade it.

Everyone here hating this video because his telling us the truth. just like Austin i wish i would love this laptop too but it really makes no sense, unless they get really big and start cutting prices.

I've heard the Price comment many times. But I don't see it. there isn't a single full aluminium built laptop bellow 1000$, they also have trash screens. the cost isn't just in the motherboard components. And in my experience cheap laptops consistently put the smallest battery they can in their laptops as the first corner they cut, and it won't stay on past an hour.

I don't disagree per say with your conclusions, but you would have more weight behind your words if you bought the bestbuy laptop and gave benchmark numbers. even if it was just one performance and one battery test. I don't think they're going to be as close as you estimated.

I dont know if austin was having a off day or something but dude just seemed to be absolutely hating on this computer company and their idea? The crybertruck and ridge ad is ironic with how he calls this out as a waste basically but then says "yea sign up for a chance to win a really cheap overpriced crappy fridge on wheels". Legit seems to have a weird hate boner for this company.

His points are not invalid. Just out of touch with the point of the Framework. Saying you can buy a new one every year, is the whole reason framework exists, so you don't have to do this. But it does come at a premium. I think his take should have been more nuanced towards getting framework to the level of dell and lenovo so they have the same buying power and development team to get better prices and more up to date hardware. But as of right now, he isn't wrong. Although I do not agree with build quality. A 490$ laptop will definitely not have a better build quality, but again, this is 1200$. So yeah, it completely wrong, but not all right either
This is why we won't ever get repairable or upgradable products. We are all going to end up with disposable tech that is only good for a year.

My main issues with this video are:
1)  the SALE price of your comparison laptop
2) not understanding that if you upgrade the CPU after purchase, you get sent a whole new motherboard (and the benefits of the new revision) not just a cpu and that you can still use your original motherboard

I dont mind paying more if it does what i need it to do. The facts that i can repair it myself and add ports when i need it is fantastic. Im a lot older now then when i “needed” the good gamer laptops. I prefer laptops that do the job i need them to do. I use a surface pro 9 now because its super portable and photoshop an lightroom works amazing on it. All i need for a long long time when it comes to photo’s. So yeah if you want a good company laptop its gonna cost you. And seeing this being (prolly) light small and adjustable on the go its price point is fair. And if you own a company its a part of youre tax write off, so its a lot cheaper. The normal average joe might not like this product, but its aiming at the corporate world. And this thing fits like a T in there.
Great video, I don't see the point of Framework when you can buy a laptop with similar specs for half the price.

It is just because of making sure that the laptop works, it takes time to work the chip into a modular system, making sure it isn't broken, and all works. You're not paying for top spec, you're paying for modularity. If it becomes mainstream, I would expect prices to drop.

The higher costs from framework are all about the economies of scale. 

Framework is a small company and can only buy a small (compared to an HP or Lenovo) batch of parts. If you buy 5,000 brand new ryzen processors, AMD might sell them for, lets say $150 each. Hoewever, if you are a large company like HP, you may be buying 500,000 and AMD might be selling them for $75 each (all numbers made up since I'm not a parts buyer for a large company...). Now extrapolate that out to every single part in the laptop plus research, design, marketing, etc. and of course you'll be paying a premium for a smaller company's product. It comes down to is it worth it to you to support that company and their goals. Who knows maybe in the future Framework will be a powerhouse and be more price comparable to a big brand or maybe they go broke.... Only time will tell but they only get bigger by people seeing what the company is doing and supporting it.
2:15 who tf pays full price for windows?! either straight up pirate it with massgravel or just use a 5$ ebay key.

Austin here actually explains it very thoroughly and his reasoning is legit. For that price and the cost for upgrading the parts is similar to just buy a new laptop, No CHANCE, even with the argument "framework is for the enthusiast and the repairability is up on the roof", it'll be a REASONABLE device/laptop to purchase, in terms of price to performance (lets face it, this is still important for everyone). All the problem here is in the price, i mean Framework is still considered new after all. I think it just needs time. 

BUT if they really want this product to NOT compete with a greater market (a market where people use laptop for work, including designing, editing, etc.), facing ASUS, LENOVO, etc. and they 100% focused for the enthusiast and tech fans (and/or developers, engineers), then yeah, putting a high price on that advantage and the uniqueness of that product is super ACCEPTABLE.

Horrible take. Comparing a boutique laptop maker to a major brand price wise is just wrong. Supply side economics are against small companies in that regard. Also 4 generations of intel CPUs and one gen of AMD should be enough to convince you they are sticking to their goals.

There's something about how he mentions CPUs that are like a year old at most as "outdated" that bothers me, I suppose viewing the price in a vacuum, then perhaps, but like repairability is such a key part that I've had my "outdated" Thinkpad T430 for years for the sheer reason that I know it's easy to fix and it still works despite being a decade old laptop, I've replaced the keyboard, the CPU, added RAM, added like two more storage, and it's a laptop that works, probably won't make it to Windows 11 (not that I'd see myself using it)

I just think that the angle of constantly upgrading your laptop isn't always viable for some of us, that we'd have to make the best with what we've got, and just having a laptop that's very easy to fix (both the labor and the parts to do so) can be an arguably better investment than just getting a cheaper laptop and realizing you happened to grab a laptop that's difficult to repair and realize you need to grab a new one, like I'd rather fork up the money upfront due to a variety of reasons

I do hope Framework gains much wider adoption so it becomes more viable to grab them secondhand

the high price is because you get a repairable laptop & i think the older parts is to keep the price down. why do you think you get from other brand a much cheaper laptop with the same parts because they don't need to invest more to keep it repairable. you pay for that

A video like this clearly displays just how unqualified Austin is to make actual tech reviews or guides. Somehow he has managed to miss the entire mark of what makes a Framework laptop appealing or why you'd want to buy one in the first place, all while shilling for Ridge and promoting the Cybertruck or any other company that's willing to put a dollar in his pocket. I guess maybe just stick with making the same "mystery tech" videos that he has been for the last 5 years to appeal to his shrinking audience
L video Austin. Also, I'd take a Framework laptop over a Ridge wallet.
Other than it didnt came with windows key, what other benefits does this diy laptop came with? The price tag alone gonna drive people away

Austin's take was solely in respect to the market the most average joe would face and that's completely fine take, that is HIS audience. But I would have liked to see some effort into diving into the ethos of the company's product (laptop) he is reviewing on, and who the actual audience for that is. They market their laptop for everyone because even if one didn't intend to have a laptop that lasts, and reduce E-waste, they would be contributing towards a better cause while also getting an okay system, and now the tech has evolved over the years - having an Okay system is all most people need including the average joe. Students, not so much like me :)
 (I am really tempted though)

The point of having that CPU upgrade is not so you can buy it every 6 months to be up to date, but to have a new system 4 years down the line to a higher spec, without adjusting to a new laptop with their own bios system, instabilities and quirks. If I own a car, I want to Own that and not be thinking like replacing the whole thing because something is cheaper to buy as a whole then just maintaining it - economics sense? ye maybe but you have to again adjust to it, get your muscle memory build over time. Besides the goal of Framework is entirely different from the market and they even standing close to competing, and desirable I might add? It is just awesome to be a part of it.

Apple ffs have been doing this since forever, people justifying the prices saying, it's for R&D, the software upgrade, the consistency and they all but given us laptops with no ports, keyboards that breaks, display that dies for no user error AT ALL. People still backed that up because of familiarity and the software ecosystem unison with their hardware (dongles and whatever but it works as the user expects) but then again, they were also being held hostage by that same company.

Whatever framework is doing is by choice, the pricing is by choice while also trying their best to price for the competition despite being a low volume manufacturer. And the users are trying prop them up to have that ecosystem last and prosper till it becomes a no brainer to stick to framework and just wait for a newer hardware that just makes sense to upgrade.

I didn't even mention about the saying the environment thing because frankly most people cannot justify buying specifically for that cause only because most can't afford that premium. If that was the case, then it would make sense for framework to never upgrade their hardware design and just bulk order just the motherboard and have that be updated every 6 months. And that is just as sad as buying a whole new laptop imo, because that ain't really solving the core cause either.

pinnacle of normie tech media, do not see value in rend user repairable and  on top not realizing each laptop for each sku need its own tooling and unlike their competitor use the same tooling for whole product line up.
I agree.  I want a laptop made by children and salves at the lowest possible price so its no big deal when I bin it in a year and buy a new one.  Tech is meant to be disposable after all.

Overrated hyped company. You are paying 30-40% more for the hype of upgrade. Heck you are paying even more for the upgrade components.

All laptops are repairable. Parts are sold in AliExpress, eBay, temu. Alienware, dell, HP, Asus etc. Replaceable motherboard, screen, keyboard, battery, etc.

I own one and I think it’s pretty sleek and premium feeling. I had a plastic gaming laptop before that was only a little less money and it felt like crap compared to the framework. Overall, I love mine and despite the price, think it is a worthwhile investment.

"The only thing better engineered than this is a Ridge wallet."
Ah, so Ridge wallet will only _partially_ sever your fingers if you close it carelessly

Framework is still a thing? It's such a niche market that not even most PC enthusiasts want a part of. You'd have to be dumb to spend this kind of money on last-gen components. You do realize they do this on purpose just to entice you to upgrade sooner as it's "so easy" to upgrade now. Every decision is made with their bottom line in mind, sure their trying really hard to make it seem like all these things work/fit so niche. But if they end up taking off, the second they see the opportunity they'll do what everyone else does... Cut costs, cut quality, cut warranty length and raise the price... The fact Linus is invested (and failed to mention it while reviewing one on LTT, then being called out and now is obnoxious about it any chance he gets.) I trust/have even less faith in this company. If this was a market, the big names would already be offering this option, or doing it this way from the beginning.
i woudl go HAM for a lil micro like 10 inch gaming laptop with a ryzen 5 and a solid gpu.....i cant justify paying these prices for a entry lvl laptop

I don't think the people buying this are going to care about having the latest hardware. If they're buying a repairable laptop, they're planning on having it for the long haul. Components that are a year old really aren't bad. I'm using a PC with an i7 8700k and a RX 5700xt. It still runs even the newest games on mid-high(very few ultra) settings, so I don't see a need to upgrade yet. I feel that is the kind of people the laptop is targeting.

Coats are more e pensive but when you consider env costs in your price they are often going to be. Just saying you could save money and further the env burden seems to miss one of the kep points of framework. Feel like this is intentionally missing the point to drum up  comments etc. Coats are more expensive, but when you consider environmental costs in your price, they are often going to be higher. Wow, I’m honestly disappointed by how shallow this review is. It’s clear Austin didn’t fully understand what the Framework Laptop is all about. And before anyone says I’m biased, I don’t even own one and can’t currently afford it, but this review feels completely wrong to me.

Framework is about more than selling another laptop—it’s about sustainability, upgradability, and giving power back to the user. Sure, you might upgrade your laptop every year or two, but good luck getting a new battery or replacing a broken USB port on most mainstream laptops. With Framework, those issues are a non-issue.

I’m not even going to get started on companies like Dell with their awful design choices—two Type-C ports only? Seriously? And if you want more RAM, you have to buy the higher storage model, which just hikes up the cost. Comparing the 'cheapest' orange to the 'cheapest' apple (fruit, not the company) is just plain wrong. They’re in completely different categories.

Yes, the Framework might seem expensive, but that’s partly because they’re still growing and don’t have the massive market share to negotiate lower component prices. But here’s the thing—with Framework, you have the freedom to shop around for cheaper SSDs and RAM, and upgrade your laptop the way *you* want, without being locked into overpriced 'upgrade' options.

Ok so, I am not one to comment often but I feel your comparison to the Lenovo to be way off, for several reasons, and it does Framework a great disservice.
And as someone that has been looking in the farthest corners for a laptop that suits me and my needs, I have looked at this Lenovo already, and the specs are horribly misleading on the product page.

The Lenovo you showed had the following specs (model: 83DK000DUS, Model number shown at 16:54)
 - Ryzen 5 8640HS (a little bit quicker than the Ryzen 5 7640U, sure)
 - 8GB of completely non-upgradeable RAM (Yes, I double-checked, you need to order enough when you buy it, Lenovo explicitly lists it as Soldered LPDDR5)

 - a 512GB SSD (likely a cheaper offering than those from Framework, which are WD Black model drives, the SN770 or SN850X)
 - a "2k" display, bonus being touch (Lenovo lists it as a 1920x1200 300nit 60Hz IPS panel, which is NOT even close to the 2.8k 2880x1920 500nit 120HZ display you got on the Framework)
 - The Lenovo is a 2-in-1 model which IS a bonus, sure
 - You compared the Lenovo at its sale price, of $450, which it is no longer on sale and is $750

So, a better comparison would be an HP Pavilion Plus 14Z-EY100 with the 1TB upgrade, which has an MSRP of $1120 for the Ryzen 5 with 16GB of RAM and a 2560x1600 120hz IPS 300nit display or $1260 for the Ryzen 7 with 16GB of RAM and the 2880x1800 120hz 400-500nit OLED display, I am sure there are other similar comparisons, but it is one I have found during my searching.

I love the content Austin but please make sure your due diligence is done for something like this, as the Framework and Lenovo are in completely different categories (a higher end version of the same Lenovo model would make a better comparison instead). I feel very as though the view taken here was very skewed to which I can say I am very disappointed, but I still look forward to future videos.

I feel like this review missed the mark on what Framework is really about. They're not trying to compete by pushing out new laptops every year with the latest tech. Instead, they’re focused on giving us a laptop that lasts—a device you can upgrade over time without breaking the bank.

In a world where replacing a screen on a $500 laptop can cost almost half of its value, or where a tiny issue with soldered components means tossing the whole laptop, Framework is a game-changer. It’s awesome to know you can have a laptop that you can tweak and upgrade as you need, rather than being stuck with whatever you bought.

There are really two types of laptop users: those who get a new one every 2-3 years and those who invest in something that’ll last. I’m definitely in the latter camp. I used a MacBook Pro from 2017 until 2022, and while it served me well, it became unusable due to battery issues. The cost to replace the battery was so high that buying a new laptop seemed like a better option. That’s where Framework comes in—if they can keep delivering reasonably priced upgrades, they might just be the future we’ve all been waiting for.

I wish the video had taken a closer look at how Framework is delivering on its promises. The only way they can compete with the big brands is if more people get on board, and negative reviews might scare off those who are curious about trying something new.

He’s ABSOLUTELY RIGHT, so why have I paid my final payment for the even more expensive Intel Core Ultra version?

It’s because he underestimates the true value proposition that the Framework 13 offers.

Firstly, he’s misunderstood the true cost: all he talks about is the upfront cost, when it’s the savings on upgrade that redress the balance. 

E.g. to upgrade to the Ryzen 5 motherboard in his video it costs just $419.  This gives an indication as to what I can expect in future…that’s a bargain!!  Plus, as Framework grows in popularity, economies of scale should push the price down.

Secondly, when you upgrade your motherboard, you can repurpose your old motherboard eg as a server and there are free downloadable 3D printer case designs for Framework motherboards. 

Therefore, upon upgrading I get TWO computers not one new one…you need to add in the price of a free secondhand computer/server into the equation.

Thirdly, computers break..it’s a fact of life and the cost of repair is negligible with Framework compared to any other brand…and some brands are impossible to repair which means you have to replace the ENTIRE LAPTOP.  This huge cost is missing from his analysis.

Fourthly, he doesn’t properly factor the value of recycling and waste prevention…he’s just another mindless consumer who moans about the environment but does nothing about it even when the solution is in his hands.  The cognitive dissonance is palpable but he dismisses it. 

Lastly, as a Linux user, it’s fantastic to have a brand that’s put support of Linux as a primary goal.

Personally, I don't think Framework is for "hardcore enthusiast", as Austin has claimed. 
I am not a computer enthusiast, and I love my framework. Here is my criteria for a good laptop:

- I only do very light computing task on my laptop, and I want good battery life, so U chip is actually an advantage for me, compare to the HS chip.
- I want my laptop to have minimal environmental impact. It should be long-lasting and produces minimal e-wastes.
- I want my laptop to have excellent Linux support, since I do not enjoy tinkering with my computers (happy to say, never `demsg`ed on my framework!)
- I want a knowledgeable support community that actually knows about computers, so that if anything actually failed, I know I can resolve it in a couple of days at most.
- I want long-term and easy firmware update for security. 
- If possible, I would prefer a nice screen.

I think my requirement embodies basically what "non-enthusiast" wants: "just works", good battery life, great support, basic security, and climate conscious. And this basically rules out most laptops out there. Most major laptop brands like Dell, HP and Lenovo all have terrible phone tree, and good luck finding anyone that actually knows what they are doing. Many of them also don't support automatic firmware update. I am not going to search for the firmware and flash it every month, that is simply not what a "non-enthusiast" would do.
In the end, the only manufactures that come close to framework are system76 and tuxedo. I eventually chose framework because of its nice 3:2 display, the upgradable CPU, and the U instead of HS processor.

Quite ironically, I believe Austin dislikes the framework precisely because he is an "enthusiast", he knows the performance differences between every laptop, and their value propositions. I personally would much prefer to not waste time in a phone tree or go on to dell forum, just to know that they are not able to fix my issue blah blah blah. With a framework, you know that all the hardware will work on Linux, with long-term support; and if anything fails, there is a huge and knowledgeable community that can help me fix it quickly.

The fact that Apple is one of the largest laptop manufacture, before their ARM transition, is a clear signal that consumers, especially non-enthusiasts like me, prefers a computer that works, instead of min-maxing on all the values on a laptop that will not be supported after a year. And I think that is the main target audiences of Framework.

When I bought my laptop, it came with, 16GB RAM, 500gb SSD, glossy screen and 11th Gen i5. Over the last 3 years, I've installed a Matte screen, 64GB of Ram, 1 TB, and the best part, installed the 12th Gen i7 board. Not to mention being able to hot swap the expansion cards as needed.

Wow, I’m honestly disappointed by how shallow this review is. It’s clear Austin didn’t fully understand what the Framework Laptop is all about. And before anyone says I’m biased, I don’t even own one and can’t currently afford it, but this review feels completely wrong to me.

Framework is about more than selling another laptop—it’s about sustainability, upgradability, and giving power back to the user. Sure, you might upgrade your laptop every year or two, but good luck getting a new battery or replacing a broken USB port on most mainstream laptops. With Framework, those issues are a non-issue.

I’m not even going to get started on companies like Dell with their awful design choices—two Type-C ports only? Seriously? And if you want more RAM, you have to buy the higher storage model, which just hikes up the cost. Comparing the 'cheapest' orange to the 'cheapest' apple (fruit, not the company) is just plain wrong. They’re in completely different categories.

Yes, the Framework might seem expensive, but that’s partly because they’re still growing and don’t have the massive market share to negotiate lower component prices. But here’s the thing—with Framework, you have the freedom to shop around for cheaper SSDs and RAM, and upgrade your laptop the way *you* want, without being locked into overpriced 'upgrade' options.

Ok so, I am not one to comment often but I feel your comparison to the Lenovo to be way off, for several reasons, and it does Framework a great disservice.
And as someone that has been looking in the farthest corners for a laptop that suits me and my needs, I have looked at this Lenovo already, and the specs are horribly misleading on the product page.

The Lenovo you showed had the following specs (model: 83DK000DUS, Model number shown at 16:54)
 - Ryzen 5 8640HS (a little bit quicker than the Ryzen 5 7640U, sure)
 - 8GB of completely non-upgradeable RAM (Yes, I double-checked, you need to order enough when you buy it, Lenovo explicitly lists it as Soldered LPDDR5)

 - a 512GB SSD (likely a cheaper offering than those from Framework, which are WD Black model drives, the SN770 or SN850X)
 - a "2k" display, bonus being touch (Lenovo lists it as a 1920x1200 300nit 60Hz IPS panel, which is NOT even close to the 2.8k 2880x1920 500nit 120HZ display you got on the Framework)
 - The Lenovo is a 2-in-1 model which IS a bonus, sure
 - You compared the Lenovo at its sale price, of $450, which it is no longer on sale and is $750

So, a better comparison would be an HP Pavilion Plus 14Z-EY100 with the 1TB upgrade, which has an MSRP of $1120 for the Ryzen 5 with 16GB of RAM and a 2560x1600 120hz IPS 300nit display or $1260 for the Ryzen 7 with 16GB of RAM and the 2880x1800 120hz 400-500nit OLED display, I am sure there are other similar comparisons, but it is one I have found during my searching.

I love the content Austin but please make sure your due diligence is done for something like this, as the Framework and Lenovo are in completely different categories (a higher end version of the same Lenovo model would make a better comparison instead). I feel very as though the view taken here was very skewed to which I can say I am very disappointed, but I still look forward to future videos.

I feel like this review missed the mark on what Framework is really about. They're not trying to compete by pushing out new laptops every year with the latest tech. Instead, they’re focused on giving us a laptop that lasts—a device you can upgrade over time without breaking the bank.

In a world where replacing a screen on a $500 laptop can cost almost half of its value, or where a tiny issue with soldered components means tossing the whole laptop, Framework is a game-changer. It’s awesome to know you can have a laptop that you can tweak and upgrade as you need, rather than being stuck with whatever you bought.

There are really two types of laptop users: those who get a new one every 2-3 years and those who invest in something that’ll last. I’m definitely in the latter camp. I used a MacBook Pro from 2017 until 2022, and while it served me well, it became unusable due to battery issues. The cost to replace the battery was so high that buying a new laptop seemed like a better option. That’s where Framework comes in—if they can keep delivering reasonably priced upgrades, they might just be the future we’ve all been waiting for.

I wish the video had taken a closer look at how Framework is delivering on its promises. The only way they can compete with the big brands is if more people get on board, and negative reviews might scare off those who are curious about trying something new.

The Problem with this Review...
1. He mentions the repairability but doesn't mention how easy it is to get parts for them instead of relying on 3rd party like his Yoga choice will be if he has to get a new screen.
2. He mentions the upgrade path to new parts but doesn't mention how you can also upgrade the whole board to a newer compatible board, without having to buy a WHOLE new laptop, and then being able to use the older board with DIY solutions.
3. He tries to pin Framework as a system that has to be sold to the open consumer market at BB and other establishments but fails to forget that this brand is mostly aimed to the audience who wants control on what can be done with their system now and in the future.
He is making lots of points to show that this is great for a laptop but hates the higher price tag, but just tries to push against it like it needs to step up.
I would rather side with the Framework group and allowing a few fans in their systems than the tiny single fan that HP tries to push on the masses.
Thanks Austin for giving Framework the spotlight it deserves instead of dragging it down because of Linus.

Agree with the premise that Framework laptops aren’t for everyday consumers, but think the video didn’t try to understand what customer / scenario might a Framework be a good option. For example:

- Most countries don’t get the crazy sales the US have, where you can get a well-built laptop like the Yoga 7 for US$500. They usually go for US$900-1000 up here in Canada (worse in other markets), so $1200 for a Framework doesn’t sound that outrageous at all. 

- Many Framework customers, who are probably somewhat tech literate, aren’t buying the RAM, SSD, chargers, etc with Framework — but are instead getting them cheaper through other retailers when there’s a sale, getting them used, etc.

- As someone who helped with managing IT in a small business before, the fact that you can obtain Framework parts easily on their website is attractive for maintaining the company’s fleet of laptops. Other manufacturers just don’t make parts available except to corporate customers who have huge IT departments. 

- In terms of customization, being able to customize the ports and the keyboard layout / language is hugely convenient. If you type in multiple languages, the only other manufacturer that offers alternative keyboard options is Apple.

- For an ultrabook, where you’re realistically doing office work or some light photo / video editing, having the latest processor doesn’t matter that much? 12th-14th Intel all share the same architecture with some minor spec bump, for example…

- Lastly, I really don’t get the comparison with custom keyboards. The customer who wants a complete laptop for $500 are probably buy $20 keyboards…not the insane custom keyboards this channel often features…

Imma jump on the framework defense train here. I bought one back at the end of 2023 or so when preorders started. And honestly it’s been more than fine for all my tasks. I can code, do some light gaming (actually, pretty much anything the steam deck can do this can do also) swap out ssds for different osses (something I do since windows gets more battery life than Linux), and just about anything that any other laptop can. I think the thing Austin is losing sight of and not stressing enough is that you can UPGRADE the mobo he’s complaining about. With that said… I do think prices for the ryzen variant should go down. It has been a while. But then again, the new ones aren’t out. And also, you’re not going to be needing the latest and greatest all the time, especially on a laptop since most of the time, you wouldn’t be able to go hardcore with it anyway. It’s for when down the line, a new processor comes out and it makes a noticeable enough improvement that swapping it makes sense. And you can’t do that with anything that costs less than this laptop (or more if you consider the MacBook honestly).

I’m not gonna go and tell everyone to buy the framework laptop. But I’ll say that it’s definitely a better long term investment (assuming framework stays in business that long 🤞🏿), than anything else for now.

1,5 years ago I decided in favor of buying a Yoga 7. Now I have multiple cracks on the plastic bezel around the screen and the plastic is shattered around both hinges. Even though I'm not a heavy duty user and mainly use it at home. Warranty repair denied claiming its due to physical damage (no it's not). Paying for the repair from my pocket, which requires replacing the entire screen section, would cost 70% of the original purchase cost.

Looking around I could hardly find any matte 2,8K display laptops on the market where I live and I'm aiming for that due to switching to Linux and needing a display without fractional scaling. The only other options I was able to find are a couple of Lenovos - Ideapad Pros and Yoga 7 Slims - priced between $1100-1400. Or some Lenovo T14s around $2200. Compared to these the Framework is not a bad deal at all, especially factoring in the repairability.

The only valid downside I agree with is the rounded corners on the screen offered only with squared bezels. I mean it just seems so straightforward to create bezels with the same rounded corners around the edges that I can't even fathom why Framework hasn't been doing it.

He’s ABSOLUTELY RIGHT, so why have I paid my final payment for the even more expensive Intel Core Ultra version?

It’s because he underestimates the true value proposition that the Framework 13 offers.

Firstly, he’s misunderstood the true cost: all he talks about is the upfront cost, when it’s the savings on upgrade that redress the balance. 

E.g. to upgrade to the Ryzen 5 motherboard in his video it costs just $419.  This gives an indication as to what I can expect in future…that’s a bargain!!  Plus, as Framework grows in popularity, economies of scale should push the price down.

Secondly, when you upgrade your motherboard, you can repurpose your old motherboard eg as a server and there are free downloadable 3D printer case designs for Framework motherboards. 

Therefore, upon upgrading I get TWO computers not one new one…you need to add in the price of a free secondhand computer/server into the equation.

Thirdly, computers break..it’s a fact of life and the cost of repair is negligible with Framework compared to any other brand…and some brands are impossible to repair which means you have to replace the ENTIRE LAPTOP.  This huge cost is missing from his analysis.

Fourthly, he doesn’t properly factor the value of recycling and waste prevention…he’s just another mindless consumer who moans about the environment but does nothing about it even when the solution is in his hands.  The cognitive dissonance is palpable but he dismisses it. 

Lastly, as a Linux user, it’s fantastic to have a brand that’s put support of Linux as a primary goal.

Personally, I don't think Framework is for "hardcore enthusiast", as Austin has claimed. 
I am not a computer enthusiast, and I love my framework. Here is my criteria for a good laptop:

- I only do very light computing task on my laptop, and I want good battery life, so U chip is actually an advantage for me, compare to the HS chip.
- I want my laptop to have minimal environmental impact. It should be long-lasting and produces minimal e-wastes.
- I want my laptop to have excellent Linux support, since I do not enjoy tinkering with my computers (happy to say, never `demsg`ed on my framework!)
- I want a knowledgeable support community that actually knows about computers, so that if anything actually failed, I know I can resolve it in a couple of days at most.
- I want long-term and easy firmware update for security. 
- If possible, I would prefer a nice screen.

I think my requirement embodies basically what "non-enthusiast" wants: "just works", good battery life, great support, basic security, and climate conscious. And this basically rules out most laptops out there. Most major laptop brands like Dell, HP and Lenovo all have terrible phone tree, and good luck finding anyone that actually knows what they are doing. Many of them also don't support automatic firmware update. I am not going to search for the firmware and flash it every month, that is simply not what a "non-enthusiast" would do.
In the end, the only manufactures that come close to framework are system76 and tuxedo. I eventually chose framework because of its nice 3:2 display, the upgradable CPU, and the U instead of HS processor.

Quite ironically, I believe Austin dislikes the framework precisely because he is an "enthusiast", he knows the performance differences between every laptop, and their value propositions. I personally would much prefer to not waste time in a phone tree or go on to dell forum, just to know that they are not able to fix my issue blah blah blah. With a framework, you know that all the hardware will work on Linux, with long-term support; and if anything fails, there is a huge and knowledgeable community that can help me fix it quickly.

The fact that Apple is one of the largest laptop manufacture, before their ARM transition, is a clear signal that consumers, especially non-enthusiasts like me, prefers a computer that works, instead of min-maxing on all the values on a laptop that will not be supported after a year. And I think that is the main target audiences of Framework.

The higher costs from framework are all about the economies of scale. 

Framework is a small company and can only buy a small (compared to an HP or Lenovo) batch of parts. If you buy 5,000 brand new ryzen processors, AMD might sell them for, lets say $150 each. Hoewever, if you are a large company like HP, you may be buying 500,000 and AMD might be selling them for $75 each (all numbers made up since I'm not a parts buyer for a large company...). Now extrapolate that out to every single part in the laptop plus research, design, marketing, etc. and of course you'll be paying a premium for a smaller company's product. It comes down to is it worth it to you to support that company and their goals. Who knows maybe in the future Framework will be a powerhouse and be more price comparable to a big brand or maybe they go broke.... Only time will tell but they only get bigger by people seeing what the company is doing and supporting it.

Wow, I’m honestly disappointed by how shallow this review is. It’s clear Austin didn’t fully understand what the Framework Laptop is all about. And before anyone says I’m biased, I don’t even own one and can’t currently afford it, but this review feels completely wrong to me.

Framework is about more than selling another laptop—it’s about sustainability, upgradability, and giving power back to the user. Sure, you might upgrade your laptop every year or two, but good luck getting a new battery or replacing a broken USB port on most mainstream laptops. With Framework, those issues are a non-issue.

I’m not even going to get started on companies like Dell with their awful design choices—two Type-C ports only? Seriously? And if you want more RAM, you have to buy the higher storage model, which just hikes up the cost. Comparing the 'cheapest' orange to the 'cheapest' apple (fruit, not the company) is just plain wrong. They’re in completely different categories.

Yes, the Framework might seem expensive, but that’s partly because they’re still growing and don’t have the massive market share to negotiate lower component prices. But here’s the thing—with Framework, you have the freedom to shop around for cheaper SSDs and RAM, and upgrade your laptop the way *you* want, without being locked into overpriced 'upgrade' options.

This review is fundamentally flawed. While I am happy to see you having a look, you are looking at the Framework laptop like it is just another laptop and not giving the proper spotlight it deserves. 

The laptop is a different kind of laptop that aims for longevity, repairability and upgradability. You can swap out a lot of parts (the main board, the RAM, storage, even the battery) and even upgrade them (For example, I am planning to swap from a 11th Gen Intel to the AMD board). You dont show updraging the board. 

The new screen's rounded corners are indeed a drawback, but looks minor to me. Thing is they either had the choice to get a squared cornered screen but make it more expensive or go with that pre made model for cheaper, and the latter was the selected choice. Blame bigger companies for making this design popular. 

To me, having a laptop being repairable AND upgradeable is something I love, even if I have to sacrifice some things.

I hope you can remake this review to shows the potential it has rather than comparing it to another laptop for performance and price, because that is not what Framework is about. They are rebuilding the path that bigger companies have abandoned for years.

Ok so, I am not one to comment often but I feel your comparison to the Lenovo to be way off, for several reasons, and it does Framework a great disservice.
And as someone that has been looking in the farthest corners for a laptop that suits me and my needs, I have looked at this Lenovo already, and the specs are horribly misleading on the product page.

The Lenovo you showed had the following specs (model: 83DK000DUS, Model number shown at 16:54)
 - Ryzen 5 8640HS (a little bit quicker than the Ryzen 5 7640U, sure)
 - 8GB of completely non-upgradeable RAM (Yes, I double-checked, you need to order enough when you buy it, Lenovo explicitly lists it as Soldered LPDDR5)

 - a 512GB SSD (likely a cheaper offering than those from Framework, which are WD Black model drives, the SN770 or SN850X)
 - a "2k" display, bonus being touch (Lenovo lists it as a 1920x1200 300nit 60Hz IPS panel, which is NOT even close to the 2.8k 2880x1920 500nit 120HZ display you got on the Framework)
 - The Lenovo is a 2-in-1 model which IS a bonus, sure
 - You compared the Lenovo at its sale price, of $450, which it is no longer on sale and is $750

So, a better comparison would be an HP Pavilion Plus 14Z-EY100 with the 1TB upgrade, which has an MSRP of $1120 for the Ryzen 5 with 16GB of RAM and a 2560x1600 120hz IPS 300nit display or $1260 for the Ryzen 7 with 16GB of RAM and the 2880x1800 120hz 400-500nit OLED display, I am sure there are other similar comparisons, but it is one I have found during my searching.

I love the content Austin but please make sure your due diligence is done for something like this, as the Framework and Lenovo are in completely different categories (a higher end version of the same Lenovo model would make a better comparison instead). I feel very as though the view taken here was very skewed to which I can say I am very disappointed, but I still look forward to future videos.

How many laptops have bezels that are magnetic, easily replaceable keyboards.. That's just the beginning.

You can swap the whole motherboard for a new gen, so you get your upgrade with just a mobo/cpu swap, the screen gets reused, the case, the e-waste is massively reduced. Oh and then you can put that old mobo /cpu into a desktop case (buy or 3D print) to continue its life. It's not DOA after an upgrade. 

Hell, I had a hinge/ case  break on an Asus, I could source the part from Ali-express for almost half of what I paid for my $400 laptop. Framework you can buy OEM parts direct, not from rando marketplace sellers on fleabay, or amazon. That's Huge!

Something interesting with Framework, the DIY options are fully assembled for testing, then broken back down again for you to assemble at home.

I feel like this review missed the mark on what Framework is really about. They're not trying to compete by pushing out new laptops every year with the latest tech. Instead, they’re focused on giving us a laptop that lasts—a device you can upgrade over time without breaking the bank.

In a world where replacing a screen on a $500 laptop can cost almost half of its value, or where a tiny issue with soldered components means tossing the whole laptop, Framework is a game-changer. It’s awesome to know you can have a laptop that you can tweak and upgrade as you need, rather than being stuck with whatever you bought.

There are really two types of laptop users: those who get a new one every 2-3 years and those who invest in something that’ll last. I’m definitely in the latter camp. I used a MacBook Pro from 2017 until 2022, and while it served me well, it became unusable due to battery issues. The cost to replace the battery was so high that buying a new laptop seemed like a better option. That’s where Framework comes in—if they can keep delivering reasonably priced upgrades, they might just be the future we’ve all been waiting for.

I wish the video had taken a closer look at how Framework is delivering on its promises. The only way they can compete with the big brands is if more people get on board, and negative reviews might scare off those who are curious about trying something new.

The Problem with this Review...
1. He mentions the repairability but doesn't mention how easy it is to get parts for them instead of relying on 3rd party like his Yoga choice will be if he has to get a new screen.
2. He mentions the upgrade path to new parts but doesn't mention how you can also upgrade the whole board to a newer compatible board, without having to buy a WHOLE new laptop, and then being able to use the older board with DIY solutions.
3. He tries to pin Framework as a system that has to be sold to the open consumer market at BB and other establishments but fails to forget that this brand is mostly aimed to the audience who wants control on what can be done with their system now and in the future.
He is making lots of points to show that this is great for a laptop but hates the higher price tag, but just tries to push against it like it needs to step up.
I would rather side with the Framework group and allowing a few fans in their systems than the tiny single fan that HP tries to push on the masses.
Thanks Austin for giving Framework the spotlight it deserves instead of dragging it down because of Linus.

Agree with the premise that Framework laptops aren’t for everyday consumers, but think the video didn’t try to understand what customer / scenario might a Framework be a good option. For example:

- Most countries don’t get the crazy sales the US have, where you can get a well-built laptop like the Yoga 7 for US$500. They usually go for US$900-1000 up here in Canada (worse in other markets), so $1200 for a Framework doesn’t sound that outrageous at all. 

- Many Framework customers, who are probably somewhat tech literate, aren’t buying the RAM, SSD, chargers, etc with Framework — but are instead getting them cheaper through other retailers when there’s a sale, getting them used, etc.

- As someone who helped with managing IT in a small business before, the fact that you can obtain Framework parts easily on their website is attractive for maintaining the company’s fleet of laptops. Other manufacturers just don’t make parts available except to corporate customers who have huge IT departments. 

- In terms of customization, being able to customize the ports and the keyboard layout / language is hugely convenient. If you type in multiple languages, the only other manufacturer that offers alternative keyboard options is Apple.

- For an ultrabook, where you’re realistically doing office work or some light photo / video editing, having the latest processor doesn’t matter that much? 12th-14th Intel all share the same architecture with some minor spec bump, for example…

- Lastly, I really don’t get the comparison with custom keyboards. The customer who wants a complete laptop for $500 are probably buy $20 keyboards…not the insane custom keyboards this channel often features…

And the custom keyboard market in the beginning was extremely expensive when it was first starting out, just because you finally got into the custom keyboard market when it's finally cheaper to actually get into it, doesn't negate the fact that it was once a very expensive hobby, and it can still be a very expensive hobby. Same as every new style of tech. P. S. You also get to reuse older framework boards and memory when just upgrading internals, just as you do when upgrading custom keyboard components on some boards.

questions:
1,5 years ago I decided in favor of buying a Yoga 7. Now I have multiple cracks on the plastic bezel around the screen and the plastic is shattered around both hinges. Even though I'm not a heavy duty user and mainly use it at home. Warranty repair denied claiming its due to physical damage (no it's not). Paying for the repair from my pocket, which requires replacing the entire screen section, would cost 70% of the original purchase cost.

Looking around I could hardly find any matte 2,8K display laptops on the market where I live and I'm aiming for that due to switching to Linux and needing a display without fractional scaling. The only other options I was able to find are a couple of Lenovos - Ideapad Pros and Yoga 7 Slims - priced between $1100-1400. Or some Lenovo T14s around $2200. Compared to these the Framework is not a bad deal at all, especially factoring in the repairability.

The only valid downside I agree with is the rounded corners on the screen offered only with squared bezels. I mean it just seems so straightforward to create bezels with the same rounded corners around the edges that I can't even fathom why Framework hasn't been doing it.

I came to this video thanks to a LTT video when people asked Linus to react to you (and he give you the reason), I agree, Framework laptops are very expensive and I suppose that is not their fault, as you say, they’re a small company and that makes difficult to negotiate better prices for the components, it would be great if they grow as a company and bring better prices.
My mom bought one kislux  and she loves it. It had been there for over 10 years when she went out with it.
Yeah, they cost more than others. But surely we should be trying to support companies who are trying to support us.

He’s ABSOLUTELY RIGHT, so why have I paid my final payment for the even more expensive Intel Core Ultra version?

It’s because he underestimates the true value proposition that the Framework 13 offers.

Firstly, he’s misunderstood the true cost: all he talks about is the upfront cost, when it’s the savings on upgrade that redress the balance. 

E.g. to upgrade to the Ryzen 5 motherboard in his video it costs just $419.  This gives an indication as to what I can expect in future…that’s a bargain!!  Plus, as Framework grows in popularity, economies of scale should push the price down.

Secondly, when you upgrade your motherboard, you can repurpose your old motherboard eg as a server and there are free downloadable 3D printer case designs for Framework motherboards. 

Therefore, upon upgrading I get TWO computers not one new one…you need to add in the price of a free secondhand computer/server into the equation.

Thirdly, computers break..it’s a fact of life and the cost of repair is negligible with Framework compared to any other brand…and some brands are impossible to repair which means you have to replace the ENTIRE LAPTOP.  This huge cost is missing from his analysis.

Fourthly, he doesn’t properly factor the value of recycling and waste prevention…he’s just another mindless consumer who moans about the environment but does nothing about it even when the solution is in his hands.  The cognitive dissonance is palpable but he dismisses it. 

Lastly, as a Linux user, it’s fantastic to have a brand that’s put support of Linux as a primary goal.

This is my theory on the page 4 scene…
This is the opening sequence of the movie. It’s a heavily disguised William Afton and a young Vanessa (“Gemma”) in the late 80s or early 90s luring a child (“Darrin”) into the basement where he plans to unalive Darrin and stuff him into one toy animatronics or Mangle. Script 4 makes the most sense with the given evidence we have so far, FNAF 2 is the only in game OG location we see with a carousel in it. The location is also referred to as “abandoned” in the script title. Unlike FNAF 2’s location which looks relatively new and a functioning business, however FNAF 2 is also a prequel to the first game, but the next movie can’t be a prequel since it is already confirmed to be set after the first film, with Josh Hutcherson returning so unless he magically gets de-aged I can’t see the new movie being set in the past, so basically having 2 or more abandoned Freddy’s locations makes sense in this timeline. 
Also regarding the “Gemma” and “Darrin” names it’s common for screenwriters to use an anonym when writing a character who’s identity is not meant to be revealed at the time, and especially since this is Scott who we are talking about who loves his secrets and red herrings. 
Scott is another reason why I’m leaning to script 4 because as much as I like script 3 I just don’t believe Scott would reveal what seems like a very critical part of the movie in a script preview, think about all the tiny details in the games he goes so far to hide and have us theorize about. It just doesn’t seem like him to reveal something this way, that’s never been his style.
So I’m pretty confident that script 4 is our winner.
