Film student here! Typically, when it comes to scripts, a general rule of thumb is one page of a script equals 1 minute in the final film, so if we're looking at the pages from a story perspective, placing them into a cohesive story... I'd say either the 3rd or 4th one flow the best, not saying that the others aren't likely either... but they do flow the best. 

For the 3rd one, Mike burning plushies in sort of a co-op mission could lead to a climax and resolution at the end of the film given it's page 58, making it around an hour mark would leave enough time for a resolution. 

Similar reasoning for the 4th one, this sequence would be early on in the film... possibly being an event from the past, which would then connect somehow to something later in the movie. 

The reason I don't think the 1st one is likely is because based on where Vanessa was left off in the first film, how likely is it that she's out of the hospital... there could be a time jump, perhaps she was watching Abby and they were kidnapped by an animatronic... but the suspense in the scene just seems too much for what would be the half hour mark in what will probably be close to a 2 hour film. 

As for the 2nd one... it's just a bit much in all honesty. This scene seems what is typically exposition, giving the audience some backstory... and it's just unusual to place this in 20 minutes in. Then again, this is Scott we're talking about... and perhaps we meet these characters earlier in the film... but I can't imagine an event taking place that would even involve the US Government with Fazbear Entertainment this early on, if at all in the franchise. 

I'm honestly happy to talk more about this too, disecting scripts is essentially what I study at school... ha!!

Hii, I'm a film graduate and I have some thoughts. This will be a LONG text (1114 words lol) explaining my opinion and I apologize if there's smth hard to understand (English isn't my first language) but, in a nutshell, I think the fourth and last script is the real one bc, from a narrative standpoint, it would make a good start for the movie AND it's written correctly (although not having numbered scenes is infuriating but alas, none of the scenes in other scripts are numbered, so maybe it's a weird standard from US filming industry, idk). 

I also think that "the man" can't be (or at least shouldn't be) any important character unlike Darrin and Gemma. Why? Well, when you hand the script to the actors and actresses, they need to know the role they are playing, so hiding the identity of the character in a script that only the staff would read and that everyone working on it knows who the character is is unnecessary and even confusing. A script is meant to guide the actors and describe ONLY what is shown on the screen objectively. 

I agree that it's weird that a dad goes into an abandoned Freddy's and KNOWS his way around (if he didn't, he wouldn't have known that the carousel has a door that leads to a staircase and wouldn't enter it without second thoughts) so my guess is that he's an employee from Freddy's, like a technician or smth similar. As to why he'd be bringing his kids to an abandoned location? Idk, maybe William ordered him to do so (either by manipulation or intimidation) or some other reason. I can imagine lots of possibilities tbh, but we won't know until the movie comes out.

But why am I so sure it's the last one? Well, I'm not 100% sure bc the third one is also very plausible to be real, but feels weird that in minute 58 of the movie (as others said down here in the comments, the numbering system of a script is 1 page is 1 minute of the film) Mike is getting ready to kinda sneak in a guarded location, either FNAF 2 location with the toy animatronics or somewhere else. The standard length for a movie is between 1h 30 min and 2h and, assuming that the film will be at least 2h, this is happening right in the middle of the film, which feels weird bc there would be 1h more of action when this feels like the start of the climax of the movie, which actually would make a bit more sense if the movie was around 1h 30 min. However, knowing that the first movie was 1h 50 min, I HIGHLY doubt that this one will be shorter bc there's A LOT more material than in the first one (for starters, there are twice as many animatronics than in the first movie that have to be narratively presented and developed and the budget of the movie is clearly a lot higher, so there's no way it will be shorter). So yeah, the third one just feels weird timing-wise.

About the second script... Well, I won't even touch the thing about remnant and government funding the pizzaplex BUT what definitively sent me off is that it's not written correctly. It might be considered nitpicking BUT as I said before, a script has to describe the actions seen on screen objectively, so the paragraph where the men and women at the table are "obviously surprised to hear that blah blah blah" is NOT an objective action. It's a description of the character's thought process and/or viewer interpretation and is a basic error in script writing. A script isn't a novel and has many rules concerning it's writing, and that's one of the basic ones that any of us film students granted us an F many times when we were starting to write scripts (I used to write novels, so I obviously learned this the hard way). Also, the annotations (the brief text under the name of the character's dialogue) are incorrect bc an annotation is an indication of the emotions or expressions that a character is doing like "(looks distressed)" or "(in a sad tone)" that are meant for the actor to understand the tone of the actions and dialogue they're doing. However, all the annotations in this script are actions like "waving a hand" or "thumping the paper", which are also written incorrectly bc ALL verbs have to be in a present tense, not in gerund bc those verbs are narrative, which I've already said that it's a no-go in script writing. So yeah, if this script is the real one, I'd be disappointed MAINLY bc that script is supposed to be written by a professional, and no professional should make such basic errors.

Finally, about the first script, for starters my brain hurts while trying to understand how the action is being presented, so that says a lot. Again, it's written like if it was a novel, which I said it's a basic error, but, aside from that, the action described is weird by itself. From a timing standpoint, this happening 25 min in the movie is simply weird: it has no flow of action purpose, feels really forced and basically this should happen either at the start of the movie where the plot conflict is presented, at the start of the climax deepening the conflict (Vanessa and Abby are tricked by William/other antagonist to do smth through Toy Chica) or at the end of the movie where the conflict is solved with a weirdly happy ending that wouldn't suit this franchise at all. Also, from a lore standpoint, it feels off that Toy Chica, out of all Toy animatronics, can talk so fluidly bc I don't remember the Toy animatronics having a complex voice box. That actually would fit more to what I remember about the Funtimes with the voice luring system and stuff. However, as literally no one else called this out, not even Dawko, I'm going to assume that I have the animatronics all mixed up.

So that would be my reasoning as to why I think the last script would be the more fitting to be an actual movie script. I just wish they number the scenes bc oh boy not numbering them just makes filming REALLY complicated for everyone in the set, and I'm talking through experience. Also, if you've read all this to the end omg you are crazy and thank you so much, I hope this was as educational for you as it was infuriating to me lol

Hey, screenwriter and author here!

I'm experienced with story structure and pacing in both screenplays and novels, and the two scripts you talked about at the very end are both very likely to be the real one!

Mystery is obviously a big part of most horror movies, so the one with the dad going to the pizzeria with his kids sounds like an extremely good set up and hook. However, it feels like the first three pages would either be crammed with info, or just barren/vague and confuse people.

The other script with Mike and Abby talking about the “plushies” is probably referencing the story of the “Velveteen Rabbit” which I loved as a kid but am now disturbed by haha. The page number being in the 50’s range tells me that it is in the middle of the script (industry standard script length for most movies is around 80-120 pages, and 1 page = 1 Minute), aka where our heroes do something that will trigger the start of the final act. 

Make what you will of this, Thanks for reading!

P.s, tell Scott I'd love to write a spinoff book featuring Carlton from the silver eyes as a paranormal investigator, I feel like it would have potential and just makes sense ;)

I think- or at least I'd like to think- that the final one was the real deal. It's usually what you're taught when script-writing, but generally 1 page of a script is equal to 1 minute screen time. The first page is just absurd. So much goes on in that scene it would feel over the top. Same with the military script. 
The page about the plushies is interesting however. It would definitely make more sense with context, maybe it's referring to a discussion the characters have already had? If something is wrong with the toy animatronics why is it up to Mike, Abby and Vanessa to fix them?
Finally, the last page. I felt like it flowed much better too, and it was a good little opening considering its only page 4. But my theory is that this little secret room is a room William created, since it seemed well hidden and not behind any ordinary staff door. I think it could have been a place he used to kill, or tamper with the animatronics in a sneaky way. 
Though god knows how this guy (I'm assuming he was a former worker) found out about it, and felt the need to bring his kids. 
Also, would it seem a bit repetitive that both films take place in an abandoned pizzeria? I'd like to think that it takes place whilst the pizzeria is still functioning, though that's unlikely....The more that I think about it, the more I believe the infected plushie script.

My major worry is this movie is going a little too fast. I know that sounds insane after waiting eight years for the first movie, but hear me out here. The first movie was amazing, obviously, the props and animatronics were genuinely perfect. It was more just fantastic and wonderful and magical seeing this movie come to life before our eyes, but that doesn’t mean it was without problems. The first Fnaf movie suffered from pacing and lack of horror. There were a lot of scenes that just kind of jumped back-and-forth between each other with no connective tissue, some characters seem to bland, even though they were complex, just because they didn’t have enough screen time. And of course the lack of blood makes things frustrating. The springlocks scene could’ve been so much better if we saw blood leaking out of the suit slowly. And obviously blood doesn’t equal horror, so, having more shots of the animatronics stalking the protagonists from the background in the darkness is necessary, keep them creepy, elevating dread to another level. I am absolutely excited about this movie, I just really hope they learn from their mistakes with the first one and make the best thing they possibly can.

Personally I believe that page 4 is the real one:

Page 25: As you said, it's a bit weird. Doesn't seem like a scene that would only be on page 25 of the film, and the tone seems very off.

Page 18: Most obviously fake one of the bunch. It's also a reference too one of the failed concepts for the first movie that scott told us about. Something regarding the army using Fazbear technology in the military or something.

Page 58: Def the 2nd most convincing one, however still probably fake. It seems like yet another reference to a failed concept, this one being the infamous "plushies take manhattan" pitch from years ago. Also Mike's line at the end doesn't seem in character for him. But your thoughts on the plushie story being an analogy is a very good point.

Page 4: Makes the most sense. This seems like a cold open to the film establishing that there was more than one location in the timeline. And the vagueness of the context of the scene makes it seem like it's real. The line "we're not here for a ride sweetie." shows a clear ulterior motive that would probably be set up in the next minutes of the script. Also it's the only one that references something from the actual fnaf 2 location and uses it as part of the story. Unlike page 25 which only references toy chica existing.

I always thought after reading ‘Dittophobia’ that it sounds like some Freddy’s locations work in the same way as the Vaults in Fallout, where some were controls, and others had specific things that made them ‘experiments’. Given Scott mention he loves sci-fi, I wouldn’t be surprised if the government one was real, especially since it was a script concept he had for the first movie as well. Lowkey hope that’s the case too, because I find that more interesting than the rest of the possible script excerpts, and would additionally make the books and all of the odd things specific to certain locations make sense.

Script 4 makes the most sense with the given evidence we have so far, FNAF 2 is the only in game OG location we see with a carousel in it. The location is also referred to as “abandoned” in the script title. Unlike FNAF 2’s location which looks relatively new and a functioning business, however FNAF 2 is also a prequel to the first game, but the next movie can’t be a prequel since it is already confirmed to be set after the first film, with Josh Hutcherson returning so unless he magically gets de-aged I can’t see the new movie being set in the past, so basically having 2 or more abandoned Freddy’s locations makes sense in this timeline. 
Also regarding the “Gemma” and “Darrin” names it’s common for screenwriters to use an anonym when writing a character who’s identity is not meant to be revealed at the time, and especially since this is Scott who we are talking about who loves his secrets and red herrings. 
Scott is another reason why I’m leaning to script 4 because as much as I like script 3 I just don’t believe Scott would reveal what seems like a very critical part of the movie in a script preview, think about all the tiny details in the games he goes so far to hide and have us theorize about. It just doesn’t seem like him to reveal something this way, that’s never been his style.
So I’m pretty confident that script 4 is our winner.

Script 4 seems most likely to me, as it deliberately involves "throwaway" characters who get offed at the beginning to establish stakes, like the hoodlums who trash the pizzeria in "FNAF 1." That would be why the page number is so low, and why there are no recognizable character names (just as Carl, Hank, Max, etc., exist just to get slaughtered). Next likely to me seems Script 1, which seems less like a conclusion to me than setting up for a plot twist, with Vanessa being forced to "free" the animatronics, only for it to be revealed that they have been set free to roam and murder on their own (or something similar). That would explain its being so early in the movie.

I think for the second script, when General Everly mentioned Drummond, saying that his sentimentality got the best of him, and it’s because his kid liked the animatronics, I think Drummond is supposed to be a fake name for Afton, as in the first movie, he said, disguised as Steve Raglin, that the owner of the place used to be a sentimental guy. And also Vanessa said that she loved the place when she was a kid, and when she introduced Mike to the animatronics, you can see how much joy she was having, as if she had a passion towards them.

Hi, film student here! For anyone who may not fully understand the page numbering system in contrast with the film, a good rule of thumb is that every page = 1 minute of screen time. So that would mean with the toy chica page, that whole thing would've happened loosely 25 minutes into the film, which would be absolutely insane in my opinion. Honestly, either of the last two seem pretty plausible, but I think most likely it'll be the third one, regarding how much it doesn't reveal about the plot plus the page number, but the last one could totally work as well!!

Film student here! Typically, when it comes to scripts, a general rule of thumb is one page of a script equals 1 minute in the final film, so if we're looking at the pages from a story perspective, placing them into a cohesive story... I'd say either the 3rd or 4th one flow the best, not saying that the others aren't likely either... but they do flow the best. 

For the 3rd one, Mike burning plushies in sort of a co-op mission could lead to a climax and resolution at the end of the film given it's page 58, making it around an hour mark would leave enough time for a resolution. 

Similar reasoning for the 4th one, this sequence would be early on in the film... possibly being an event from the past, which would then connect somehow to something later in the movie. 

The reason I don't think the 1st one is likely is because based on where Vanessa was left off in the first film, how likely is it that she's out of the hospital... there could be a time jump, perhaps she was watching Abby and they were kidnapped by an animatronic... but the suspense in the scene just seems too much for what would be the half hour mark in what will probably be close to a 2 hour film. 

As for the 2nd one... it's just a bit much in all honesty. This scene seems what is typically exposition, giving the audience some backstory... and it's just unusual to place this in 20 minutes in. Then again, this is Scott we're talking about... and perhaps we meet these characters earlier in the film... but I can't imagine an event taking place that would even involve the US Government with Fazbear Entertainment this early on, if at all in the franchise. 

I'm honestly happy to talk more about this too, disecting scripts is essentially what I study at school... ha!!

Hii, I'm a film graduate and I have some thoughts. This will be a LONG text (1114 words lol) explaining my opinion and I apologize if there's smth hard to understand (English isn't my first language) but, in a nutshell, I think the fourth and last script is the real one bc, from a narrative standpoint, it would make a good start for the movie AND it's written correctly (although not having numbered scenes is infuriating but alas, none of the scenes in other scripts are numbered, so maybe it's a weird standard from US filming industry, idk). 

I also think that "the man" can't be (or at least shouldn't be) any important character unlike Darrin and Gemma. Why? Well, when you hand the script to the actors and actresses, they need to know the role they are playing, so hiding the identity of the character in a script that only the staff would read and that everyone working on it knows who the character is is unnecessary and even confusing. A script is meant to guide the actors and describe ONLY what is shown on the screen objectively. 

I agree that it's weird that a dad goes into an abandoned Freddy's and KNOWS his way around (if he didn't, he wouldn't have known that the carousel has a door that leads to a staircase and wouldn't enter it without second thoughts) so my guess is that he's an employee from Freddy's, like a technician or smth similar. As to why he'd be bringing his kids to an abandoned location? Idk, maybe William ordered him to do so (either by manipulation or intimidation) or some other reason. I can imagine lots of possibilities tbh, but we won't know until the movie comes out.

But why am I so sure it's the last one? Well, I'm not 100% sure bc the third one is also very plausible to be real, but feels weird that in minute 58 of the movie (as others said down here in the comments, the numbering system of a script is 1 page is 1 minute of the film) Mike is getting ready to kinda sneak in a guarded location, either FNAF 2 location with the toy animatronics or somewhere else. The standard length for a movie is between 1h 30 min and 2h and, assuming that the film will be at least 2h, this is happening right in the middle of the film, which feels weird bc there would be 1h more of action when this feels like the start of the climax of the movie, which actually would make a bit more sense if the movie was around 1h 30 min. However, knowing that the first movie was 1h 50 min, I HIGHLY doubt that this one will be shorter bc there's A LOT more material than in the first one (for starters, there are twice as many animatronics than in the first movie that have to be narratively presented and developed and the budget of the movie is clearly a lot higher, so there's no way it will be shorter). So yeah, the third one just feels weird timing-wise.

About the second script... Well, I won't even touch the thing about remnant and government funding the pizzaplex BUT what definitively sent me off is that it's not written correctly. It might be considered nitpicking BUT as I said before, a script has to describe the actions seen on screen objectively, so the paragraph where the men and women at the table are "obviously surprised to hear that blah blah blah" is NOT an objective action. It's a description of the character's thought process and/or viewer interpretation and is a basic error in script writing. A script isn't a novel and has many rules concerning it's writing, and that's one of the basic ones that any of us film students granted us an F many times when we were starting to write scripts (I used to write novels, so I obviously learned this the hard way). Also, the annotations (the brief text under the name of the character's dialogue) are incorrect bc an annotation is an indication of the emotions or expressions that a character is doing like "(looks distressed)" or "(in a sad tone)" that are meant for the actor to understand the tone of the actions and dialogue they're doing. However, all the annotations in this script are actions like "waving a hand" or "thumping the paper", which are also written incorrectly bc ALL verbs have to be in a present tense, not in gerund bc those verbs are narrative, which I've already said that it's a no-go in script writing. So yeah, if this script is the real one, I'd be disappointed MAINLY bc that script is supposed to be written by a professional, and no professional should make such basic errors.

Finally, about the first script, for starters my brain hurts while trying to understand how the action is being presented, so that says a lot. Again, it's written like if it was a novel, which I said it's a basic error, but, aside from that, the action described is weird by itself. From a timing standpoint, this happening 25 min in the movie is simply weird: it has no flow of action purpose, feels really forced and basically this should happen either at the start of the movie where the plot conflict is presented, at the start of the climax deepening the conflict (Vanessa and Abby are tricked by William/other antagonist to do smth through Toy Chica) or at the end of the movie where the conflict is solved with a weirdly happy ending that wouldn't suit this franchise at all. Also, from a lore standpoint, it feels off that Toy Chica, out of all Toy animatronics, can talk so fluidly bc I don't remember the Toy animatronics having a complex voice box. That actually would fit more to what I remember about the Funtimes with the voice luring system and stuff. However, as literally no one else called this out, not even Dawko, I'm going to assume that I have the animatronics all mixed up.

So that would be my reasoning as to why I think the last script would be the more fitting to be an actual movie script. I just wish they number the scenes bc oh boy not numbering them just makes filming REALLY complicated for everyone in the set, and I'm talking through experience. Also, if you've read all this to the end omg you are crazy and thank you so much, I hope this was as educational for you as it was infuriating to me lol

Important things to note about the 4th script version: In screenplays, whenever a new character is introduced in the story (just meaning one that hasn't been shown in the film yet), their name is put in ALL CAPS, and sometimes a brief description is given of their appearance. None of the characters in the 4th version were capitalized when first mentioned; So, this would mean that all 3 of the characters in that scene had been pre-introduced in one of the previous 3 pages.

Hey, screenwriter and author here!

I'm experienced with story structure and pacing in both screenplays and novels, and the two scripts you talked about at the very end are both very likely to be the real one!

Mystery is obviously a big part of most horror movies, so the one with the dad going to the pizzeria with his kids sounds like an extremely good set up and hook. However, it feels like the first three pages would either be crammed with info, or just barren/vague and confuse people.

The other script with Mike and Abby talking about the “plushies” is probably referencing the story of the “Velveteen Rabbit” which I loved as a kid but am now disturbed by haha. The page number being in the 50’s range tells me that it is in the middle of the script (industry standard script length for most movies is around 80-120 pages, and 1 page = 1 Minute), aka where our heroes do something that will trigger the start of the final act. 

Make what you will of this, Thanks for reading!

P.s, tell Scott I'd love to write a spinoff book featuring Carlton from the silver eyes as a paranormal investigator, I feel like it would have potential and just makes sense ;)

I think- or at least I'd like to think- that the final one was the real deal. It's usually what you're taught when script-writing, but generally 1 page of a script is equal to 1 minute screen time. The first page is just absurd. So much goes on in that scene it would feel over the top. Same with the military script. 
The page about the plushies is interesting however. It would definitely make more sense with context, maybe it's referring to a discussion the characters have already had? If something is wrong with the toy animatronics why is it up to Mike, Abby and Vanessa to fix them?
Finally, the last page. I felt like it flowed much better too, and it was a good little opening considering its only page 4. But my theory is that this little secret room is a room William created, since it seemed well hidden and not behind any ordinary staff door. I think it could have been a place he used to kill, or tamper with the animatronics in a sneaky way. 
Though god knows how this guy (I'm assuming he was a former worker) found out about it, and felt the need to bring his kids. 
Also, would it seem a bit repetitive that both films take place in an abandoned pizzeria? I'd like to think that it takes place whilst the pizzeria is still functioning, though that's unlikely....The more that I think about it, the more I believe the infected plushie script.

Personally I believe that page 4 is the real one:

Page 25: As you said, it's a bit weird. Doesn't seem like a scene that would only be on page 25 of the film, and the tone seems very off.

Page 18: Most obviously fake one of the bunch. It's also a reference too one of the failed concepts for the first movie that scott told us about. Something regarding the army using Fazbear technology in the military or something.

Page 58: Def the 2nd most convincing one, however still probably fake. It seems like yet another reference to a failed concept, this one being the infamous "plushies take manhattan" pitch from years ago. Also Mike's line at the end doesn't seem in character for him. But your thoughts on the plushie story being an analogy is a very good point.

Page 4: Makes the most sense. This seems like a cold open to the film establishing that there was more than one location in the timeline. And the vagueness of the context of the scene makes it seem like it's real. The line "we're not here for a ride sweetie." shows a clear ulterior motive that would probably be set up in the next minutes of the script. Also it's the only one that references something from the actual fnaf 2 location and uses it as part of the story. Unlike page 25 which only references toy chica existing.

Lowkey hope that’s the case too, because I find that more interesting than the rest of the possible script excerpts, and would additionally make the books and all of the odd things specific to certain locations make sense.

Scott, I would propose an alternative explanation for the waffling of Boeing and the Leadership there.  Boeing has been led by leadership over the last couple of decades that has been very cavalier about safety vs. "the bottom line".  They have been caught up in massive lawsuits and bad press and don't at this point need any more of that.  They want to take the chance and send the astronauts home on the Starliner, buuuut the standard risk you talk about has suddenly become a more important and concern than previous due the sudden attack of risk aversion.  I think this is the more important issue and the bad press from keeping the Astronauts up there is much less than the risk of possible catastrophe on re-entry, as long as the potential for fixing the issues and lowering the risk on the Starliner re-entry.  Boeing has not previously been too risk averse in the Aircraft safety defects dropping planes out the skies and killing thousands of people, but the consequences of that attitude have been much more severe than they have calculated and planned for in their financial spreadsheet.  Just my personal opinion!  I personally think their best outcome would be to bring the Astronauts home on Dragon and send the Starliner home by itself.  If it fails re-entry, the leadership can claim good precautionary judgement and if it survives re-entry, they can claim good judgement in not risking the Astronauts.   The only other factor is what Boeing would consider is the embarrassment of having to be bailed out by Elon Musk, but I think their spinmeisters in their Company can spin this to mitigate the embarrassment factorf quite well.  Again, just my personal opinion.  Thanks for the opportunity to expound.

*Summary*

* *[**0:00**]* *Extended Stay:* Astronauts on Starliner face a potentially much longer stay on the ISS due to ongoing technical issues. An 8-day mission could turn into an 8-month one. 
* *[**1:16**]* *Contingency Plans:* NASA has backup plans ready if Starliner can't safely return the astronauts. Options include:
    * *[**1:47**]* Sending a Dragon spacecraft with only two astronauts instead of four, bringing the Starliner crew back after 6 more months on the ISS.
    * *[**2:08**]* Utilizing the cargo pallet on the Crew-8 Dragon for astronaut return.
* *[**2:34**]* *Safety Concerns:* NASA is hesitant about clearing Starliner for re-entry due to unresolved technical issues, prioritizing astronaut safety above all else. The upcoming US election adds another layer of pressure on decision-making. 
* *[**4:57**]* *Thruster Issues:* Five maneuvering thrusters underperformed during approach to the ISS. While four are now back online, the cause remains uncertain. 
* *[**7:01**]* *Potential Cause:* Boeing believes the issue might stem from Teflon seals inside the oxidizer poppets (valves). Overheating may have caused the seals to extrude, interfering with oxidizer flow.
* *[**9:18**]* *Blame Game:* This incident might spark another dispute between Boeing and Aerojet Rocketdyne (thruster manufacturer) regarding responsibility for the technical failure.  
* *[**5:56**]* *Software Concerns:* Configuration changes made to the software for crewed flight haven't been fully tested due to Boeing's cost-cutting measures. 
* *[**11:48**]* *Future Implications:* Even if Starliner returns without crew, Boeing could push for operational status, despite the need for technical fixes. However, the limited availability of Atlas V rockets for future launches poses a significant challenge.

It sounds like they have to upload all the guidance data for an unmanned return, if NASA decides they want to go with an un-manned return.  I'm sure the guidance-package is a very large set of files (at least relative to the ISS download speeds).  And, I'm guessing here, they probably would attempt to upload it directly to the Starliner - not go to a computer on-board then kick it over to a thumbdrive and install it that way.  I'm confident that, if they go the route of having to upload it the ISS and then transfer it to spacecraft manually, they will probably have to write a program to upload and install on the ISS onboard computer that can read the Boeing guidance-package (because it's certainly formatted in a protocol that their current computers cannot understand).  No matter how they do it - the file is going to have to get transferred (after it has been written, error-checked, debugged, and formatted for transfer) over the course of hours or days and will be tying up a lot NASA and the ISS's data-transfer resources for quite some time.  Then they are going to have to repeat the process in reverse to make sure the file they sent up was received, unpacked, and installed without any corruption.  Basically, they will need to make sure the file they get back is the same file as the one they sent up and the Starliner guidance system doesn't see anything it doesn't like and spit the whole thing back out.  If they can, I imagine they want to upload directly to the Starliner via it's onboard antennas - but, between the communications going between the ISS and ground and the fact that they are hanging out in the middle of the ionosphere - they are very likely to have major interference problems if this wasn't a contingency the Boeing guys planned on.

Before any of the Thrusters, Doghouses, Poppets, etc. are ever built, every component is subject to a PDR (Preliminary Design Review) where NASA, Boeing, and The Sub Contractor  review, agree, and approve any design for a proposed component.  NASA and Boeing, will make suggestions for changes (based on their experts experience) to the proposed design with "action items" that have to be completed by the builder before manufacture of the component can start. The builder then manufactures the "First Article or Pathfinder" component which then is tested to the customer's requirements.  The results of the testing are then reviewed again by NASA and Boeing at a CDR (Critical Design Review).  The contractor is usually given another "action item" burn-down list to complete before any "Production Parts" can be manufactured.  In the case of any of the working components on Starliner, NASA, Boeing and the supplier were all in agreement before production of any Doghouse Components were ever built.  Usually the testing regimen far exceeds whatever expected operating conditions during a nominal flight usually by a multiple factor. In this case it sounds like the environmental testing that did occur, did not expose this weakness in the system.  There is lot more going on here than most people realize.

I remember that there were communications problems during the first uncrewed Starliner test, and I don't think they want the software to simply disable an underperforming thruster and fail-over to human ground control if there's any possibility of loss of contact while trying to avoid a collision with the ISS.  While I'm not a big Boeing fan, I do think that Starliner really isn't that far off from being safe and reliable transport to and from the ISS. Scott, I would propose an alternative explanation for the waffling of Boeing and the Leadership there.  Boeing has been led by leadership over the last couple of decades that has been very cavalier about safety vs. "the bottom line".  They have been caught up in massive lawsuits and bad press and don't at this point need any more of that.  They want to take the chance and send the astronauts home on the Starliner, buuuut the standard risk you talk about has suddenly become a more important and concern than previous due the sudden attack of risk aversion.  I think this is the more important issue and the bad press from keeping the Astronauts up there is much less than the risk of possible catastrophe on re-entry, as long as the potential for fixing the issues and lowering the risk on the Starliner re-entry.  Boeing has not previously been too risk averse in the Aircraft safety defects dropping planes out the skies and killing thousands of people, but the consequences of that attitude have been much more severe than they have calculated and planned for in their financial spreadsheet.  Just my personal opinion!  I personally think their best outcome would be to bring the Astronauts home on Dragon and send the Starliner home by itself.  If it fails re-entry, the leadership can claim good precautionary judgement and if it survives re-entry, they can claim good judgement in not risking the Astronauts.   The only other factor is what Boeing would consider is the embarrassment of having to be bailed out by Elon Musk, but I think their spinmeisters in their Company can spin this to mitigate the embarrassment factorf quite well.  Again, just my personal opinion.  Thanks for the opportunity to expound.

Ah teflon. My prior company used huge teflon pipes as insulator for the high voltage side of electro static dust collectors. That worked well until reaching a fume temperature of about 220°C. Then the teflon pipes began bubbling up, expanding by a good third of their size and after that, if those received even more heat, they became brittle like styrofoam. That's the reason, why teflon isn't a good sealing material when it involves heat! Better for that is the red coloured silicone, up to 350°C or the black coloured high temp silicon up to a 1000°C. And I never worked in material R&D or aviation, I worked in biomass oven industry. 😂

It doesn't take a very experienced engineer to know Teflon is a shitty seal material. It is too soft and will cold flow badly. That is why Tefzel and perflouroelastomer (viton et al) o-rings were developed. Hell Teflon isn't even very good wire insulation for the very same reasons.

I think it's time that Boeing cut their losses on this project, it was a (several times) failed experiment, and now lives are on the line.
Same story as the Shuttle really, insufficient testing, under-funded, optimizing for cost rather than performance, and while several things happened to cause it, I place blame purely on one fact that has caused Boeing to be a shambling zombified corpse of it's former "No such thing as a bad Boeing product" self:
The fact is, Boeing was great for one reason. It was engineers all the way up, from the people in the drafting rooms all the way up to the board of directors. That changed at roughly the same time as Boeing acquired McDonnal-Douglas.
Now upper management is all "bean-counter" accountant/marketing types. They lack the education to understand the product their business produces, and so the quality and safety of that product suffers greatly for it.
They're optimizing for shareholder profits, and not for product performance.
The airplanes aren't the product anymore. The stock price is. And so if you want an airplane from Boeing and not profits from owning stock, you're going to get a sub-par product.

There's a similar reality distortion which has happened with YouTube's management decisions in the past few years (more apparent the more recent the decision was made).
Creators aren't the customer. Neither is the viewer. The ad providers are the customer, because they're the ones providing the vast majority of the income. What does that make the creators and the viewers? It makes us the product, we're cultivated and harvested like wheat, as long as we keep watching ads and keep making videos to put ads on (even if the creators themselves don't make any money on those ads).
Dark patterns everywhere you look, and I only started noticing them in late 2016. Can't find the "block this user" button anymore? Youtube has decided it wants you to see all the videos, even the ones you don't want to see, because the ones you don't want to see are the ones it thinks you are most likely to sit thru and comment on (and by doing so, be subjected to the ads, which pays YouTube).

Even if each system is fully tested, what isn't tested is the work of hundreds of individuals, any one of whom might make a mistake that will never be found until the accident investigation.
Full reusability of the entire ship and capsule is the only solution that ensures safety, and allows inspection of the entire stack after flight.

If the seal problem was caused by overheating, what would prevent a repeat of the problem with other thrusters during return, especially the rear-facing ones?  Because of this uncertainty I'm more inclined to believe that Boeing wants to update the automation software to handle RCS thruster failures better on return than it did during the docking procedure.  It doesn't make sense that it would take a month for them to simply dust-off previously-used automation software.  I remember that there were communications problems during the first uncrewed Starliner test, and I don't think they want the software to simply disable an underperforming thruster and fail-over to human ground control if there's any possibility of loss of contact while trying to avoid a collision with the ISS.  While I'm not a big Boeing fan, I do think that Starliner really isn't that far off from being safe and reliable transport to and from the ISS.  They just have to get over what looks like a perfect storm of relatively minor problems that are combining into a potential disaster.  Thanks for the additional insight to this situation...

Software problems also arose early in the Apollo era. Margaret Hamilton discovered a potential problem with the Apollo Guidance Computer (AGC) when her daughter, who often accompanied her to work, was playing in a simulator. Her daughter accidentally selected a prelaunch program (P01) during a flight, something astronauts would normally never do. This incident led Hamilton to alert her superiors and advocate for more robust error handling mechanisms.

Although her warnings were initially ignored, it turned out that this very error had been made by James Lovell during the Apollo 8 mission.

Scott, I would propose an alternative explanation for the waffling of Boeing and the Leadership there.  Boeing has been led by leadership over the last couple of decades that has been very cavalier about safety vs. "the bottom line".  They have been caught up in massive lawsuits and bad press and don't at this point need any more of that.  They want to take the chance and send the astronauts home on the Starliner, buuuut the standard risk you talk about has suddenly become a more important and concern than previous due the sudden attack of risk aversion.  I think this is the more important issue and the bad press from keeping the Astronauts up there is much less than the risk of possible catastrophe on re-entry, as long as the potential for fixing the issues and lowering the risk on the Starliner re-entry.  Boeing has not previously been too risk averse in the Aircraft safety defects dropping planes out the skies and killing thousands of people, but the consequences of that attitude have been much more severe than they have calculated and planned for in their financial spreadsheet.  Just my personal opinion!  I personally think their best outcome would be to bring the Astronauts home on Dragon and send the Starliner home by itself.  If it fails re-entry, the leadership can claim good precautionary judgement and if it survives re-entry, they can claim good judgement in not risking the Astronauts.   The only other factor is what Boeing would consider is the embarrassment of having to be bailed out by Elon Musk, but I think their spinmeisters in their Company can spin this to mitigate the embarrassment factorf quite well.  Again, just my personal opinion.  Thanks for the opportunity to expound.

*Summary*

* *[**0:00**]* *Extended Stay:* Astronauts on Starliner face a potentially much longer stay on the ISS due to ongoing technical issues. An 8-day mission could turn into an 8-month one. 
* *[**1:16**]* *Contingency Plans:* NASA has backup plans ready if Starliner can't safely return the astronauts. Options include:
    * *[**1:47**]* Sending a Dragon spacecraft with only two astronauts instead of four, bringing the Starliner crew back after 6 more months on the ISS.
    * *[**2:08**]* Utilizing the cargo pallet on the Crew-8 Dragon for astronaut return.
* *[**2:34**]* *Safety Concerns:* NASA is hesitant about clearing Starliner for re-entry due to unresolved technical issues, prioritizing astronaut safety above all else. The upcoming US election adds another layer of pressure on decision-making. 
* *[**4:57**]* *Thruster Issues:* Five maneuvering thrusters underperformed during approach to the ISS. While four are now back online, the cause remains uncertain. 
* *[**7:01**]* *Potential Cause:* Boeing believes the issue might stem from Teflon seals inside the oxidizer poppets (valves). Overheating may have caused the seals to extrude, interfering with oxidizer flow.
* *[**9:18**]* *Blame Game:* This incident might spark another dispute between Boeing and Aerojet Rocketdyne (thruster manufacturer) regarding responsibility for the technical failure.  
* *[**5:56**]* *Software Concerns:* Configuration changes made to the software for crewed flight haven't been fully tested due to Boeing's cost-cutting measures. 
* *[**11:48**]* *Future Implications:* Even if Starliner returns without crew, Boeing could push for operational status, despite the need for technical fixes. However, the limited availability of Atlas V rockets for future launches poses a significant challenge.

Ah teflon. My prior company used huge teflon pipes as insulator for the high voltage side of electro static dust collectors. That worked well until reaching a fume temperature of about 220°C. Then the teflon pipes began bubbling up, expanding by a good third of their size and after that, if those received even more heat, they became brittle like styrofoam. That's the reason, why teflon isn't a good sealing material when it involves heat! Better for that is the red coloured silicone, up to 350°C or the black coloured high temp silicon up to a 1000°C. And I never worked in material R&D or aviation, I worked in biomass oven industry. 😂

It doesn't take a very experienced engineer to know Teflon is a shitty seal material. It is too soft and will cold flow badly. That is why Tefzel and perflouroelastomer (viton et al) o-rings were developed. Hell Teflon isn't even very good wire insulation for the very same reasons.

It sounds like they have to upload all the guidance data for an unmanned return, if NASA decides they want to go with an un-manned return.  I'm sure the guidance-package is a very large set of files (at least relative to the ISS download speeds).  And, I'm guessing here, they probably would attempt to upload it directly to the Starliner - not go to a computer on-board then kick it over to a thumbdrive and install it that way.  I'm confident that, if they go the route of having to upload it the ISS and then transfer it to spacecraft manually, they will probably have to write a program to upload and install on the ISS onboard computer that can read the Boeing guidance-package (because it's certainly formatted in a protocol that their current computers cannot understand).  No matter how they do it - the file is going to have to get transferred (after it has been written, error-checked, debugged, and formatted for transfer) over the course of hours or days and will be tying up a lot NASA and the ISS's data-transfer resources for quite some time.  Then they are going to have to repeat the process in reverse to make sure the file they sent up was received, unpacked, and installed without any corruption.  Basically, they will need to make sure the file they get back is the same file as the one they sent up and the Starliner guidance system doesn't see anything it doesn't like and spit the whole thing back out.  If they can, I imagine they want to upload directly to the Starliner via it's onboard antennas - but, between the communications going between the ISS and ground and the fact that they are hanging out in the middle of the ionosphere - they are very likely to have major interference problems if this wasn't a contingency the Boeing guys planned on.

Before any of the Thrusters, Doghouses, Poppets, etc. are ever built, every component is subject to a PDR (Preliminary Design Review) where NASA, Boeing, and The Sub Contractor  review, agree, and approve any design for a proposed component.  NASA and Boeing, will make suggestions for changes (based on their experts experience) to the proposed design with "action items" that have to be completed by the builder before manufacture of the component can start. The builder then manufactures the "First Article or Pathfinder" component which then is tested to the customer's requirements.  The results of the testing are then reviewed again by NASA and Boeing at a CDR (Critical Design Review).  The contractor is usually given another "action item" burn-down list to complete before any "Production Parts" can be manufactured.  In the case of any of the working components on Starliner, NASA, Boeing and the supplier were all in agreement before production of any Doghouse Components were ever built.  Usually the testing regimen far exceeds whatever expected operating conditions during a nominal flight usually by a multiple factor. In this case it sounds like the environmental testing that did occur, did not expose this weakness in the system.  There is lot more going on here than most people realize.

Software problems also arose early in the Apollo era. Margaret Hamilton discovered a potential problem with the Apollo Guidance Computer (AGC) when her daughter, who often accompanied her to work, was playing in a simulator. Her daughter accidentally selected a prelaunch program (P01) during a flight, something astronauts would normally never do. This incident led Hamilton to alert her superiors and advocate for more robust error handling mechanisms.

Although her warnings were initially ignored, it turned out that this very error had been made by James Lovell during the Apollo 8 mission.

Although I assume it is pretty much entirely Boeing engineers who are working on investigating the issues and coming up with potential fixes I assume that it is NASAstaff, staff who otherwise would have been working on other stuff, who are having to pull together these various contingency options such as bringing back the astronauts using the Crew 8 cargo area or only launching 2 astronauts on Crew 9 to enable the Starliner astronaut return (and who knows what other options took time to evaluate and then reject). And then there's the general disruption to the ISS schedule, again presumably requiring NASA to allocate its own resource to plan around those disruptions, something that wouldn't have been necessary had this Starliner mission not gone so far off its mission plan.

Basically I'm thinking there must be a load of consequential losses to NASA as a result of this Starliner failure and I really hope that NASA is going to be able to come after Boeing for compensation for disruption to its other activities once everyone is safe. I fear though that there might be specific wording in the Starliner contract precluding any Boeing liability for NASA consequential losses but I hope I'm wrong.
